column1: Holbrook (Navajo: Tʼiisyaakin) is a city in Navajo County
column2: Arizona
column3: United States.  According to the 2010 census
column4: the population of the city was 5
column5: 053. The city is the county seat of Navajo County.Holbrook was founded in 1881 or 1882
column7: and named to honor the first chief engineer of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad

column1: The Holbrook area was inhabited first by the Anasazi
column2: then Puebloans
column3: then the Navajo and Apache. In 1540 (some seventy years before Jamestown or the Pilgrims) Coronado searched for the Seven Cities of Cibola and camped some 60 miles east of Holbrook.  Coronado sent an expedition west to find the Colorado River
column4: and they crossed the Little Colorado some twenty-five miles east of Holbrook and found a wonderland of colors they named "El Desierto Pintada" - The Painted Desert.  The expedition was then led by the Hopis to the Grand Canyon.

column1: After the Mexican–American War ended in 1848 the area was ceded to the United States. From 1851-57 the U.S. Army sent three expeditions along the 35th parallel
column2: the third led by Lt. Beale who created a ten foot wide wagon road.  The area was known as Navajo Springs
column3: after a spring a dozen miles northeast of Holbrook. Soon afterwards a store and saloon were established at the confluence of the Rio Puerco and Little Colorado Rivers two miles east of Holbrook
column4: and the area became known as Horsehead Crossing.

column2: Mormons emigrated from Utah and began settlements near Horsehead Crossing on both the Little Colorado and Rio Puerco rivers. During 1881 and 1882
column3: railroad tracks were laid down and a railroad station was built to supply wood and water and to freight supplies south to Fort Apache. The community was then named Holbrook after the first engineer of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad. The railroad sold a million acres to a Boston investment group which established the Aztec Land and Cattle Company
column4: better known as the Hashknife Outfit. It leased another million acres of government land and became one of the largest cattle ranches to ever exist. Holbrook became its headquarters and quickly grew into a cow-town.

column2: many of whom were wanted men hiding from arrest.  Rustling of cattle and horses over two million acres plagued the Hashknife Outfit. With cowmen
column5: rustlers and outlaws competing for the same land
column7: called both the Pleasant Valley War and the Tonto Basin War. It likely killed as many men as any of the western range wars.  Many of the events that played out during the Pleasant Valley War up to 1887 occurred in and around Holbrook

column5: came to Holbrook to arrest Andy Blevins
column7: for horse theft. Blevins had also recently bragged about killing two men and had killed many more

column1: Sheriff Owens insisted on confronting the Blevins brothers alone
column2: knowing there would likely be a shootout. He went to the Blevins house
column5: and when Blevins asked what he wanted
column6: announced he'd come to arrest him. Blevins resisted arrest and a shootout occurred.  Blevins
column9: and Blevins horse were shot; all died

column2: despite being shot at from a half-dozen feet away.  Owens single-handedly taking on four men made him a western legend rivaling the Earp Brothers and Texas John Slaughter as lawmen of the Old West.

column1: Holbrook was known as "the town too tough for women and churches" and in 1914 was said to be the only county seat in the U.S. that didn't have a church (the Mormons had moved 25 miles south to Snowflake and Taylor).  The original railroad station was replaced by the Santa Fe Depot in 1892.

Navajo County was divided off of Apache County in 1895 and Holbrook became the county seat. Many lawmen and cowboys from the area became Rough Riders with Theodore Roosevelt in the late 1800s.  But by 1902
column2: The Hashknife Outfit was bankrupt and the land was sold to the Babbitt brothers.

column1: President Roosevelt named the Petrified Forest (including part of the Painted Desert) a National Monument in 1906.  Holbrook was incorporated in 1917.  Most of the Beale Wagon Road became Route 66 in 1926 and passed through both the Petrified Forest and Holbrook.  Tourism started taking over the economy.
Arizona is famous for its huge Meteor Crater
column2: but Holbrook also witnessed its own small meteor event. In the evening of July 19
column4: a smoke trail appeared in the sky and soon after
column6: a meteorite with an estimated mass of 190 kilograms (419 pounds) exploded high in the atmosphere.

column2: 000 or more minor fragments rained down over Navajo County in an area about 6 miles east of Holbrook. The primary explosion was heard at least 40 miles away and one of the witnesses in Holbrook
column4: described the event as the loudest sound she ever heard. The largest piece of the Holbrook Meteorite that has been recovered was found shortly after. It weighs 14.5 pounds and resides at Arizona State University in Tempe.

column1: The Holbrook meteorite was found to be of the chondrite (stony) type.

column1: The Navajo County Courthouse in downtown Holbrook was built in 1898. It is now used by the Navajo County Historical Society and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

Primary and secondary schoolsThe city is served by the Holbrook Unified School District and serves 2324 students.
Three elementary schools: Park Elementary School (K–2) and Hulet Elementary School (3–5) serve the city and Indian Wells Elementary (K–6) serves the northern parts of the school district.
Holbrook Junior High School (6–8) and Holbrook High School (9–12) serve the city.
Colleges and universitiesOne of the four main campuses of Northland Pioneer College community college is located in Holbrook.  The other three main campuses are in Show Low
